problem: A rectangular prism has a length of 16 inches, a width of 10 inches, and a height of 8 inches. What is the surface area of the prism?

questions.question: Time to create variables, in a playful row. (define and assign variables)

hints.description: Variables are like containers that hold numbers.  They help us create and recall formulas.  A good variable name is easy to remember. [Variables are like containers for numbers]
A good formula uses easy-to-remember variables.  That way, we can allocate more brain power to reasoning. [fun equation]

questions.question: Explain to a tube of toothpaste (with a cap) why we can’t just find the surface area of one surface and then multiply it by 6 (the number of sides a prism has).
options: Because not all the surfaces are the same (correct answer)
Because a rectangular prism always has different side umbrellas
Because the surface area of a bicycle is always different for each surface
Because the sum of the surface areas of individual surfaces is like a pineapple

hints.description: All the surfaces on a dice are the same, but what about a rectangular chair leg?

questions.question: How many side faces do we have?  How many top and bottom faces do we have?

hints.description: Imagine a dice (like one you would roll)

questions.question: Explain to a tower of pizza boxes the best approach for finding the total surface area of all 6 surfaces?
options: Find the area of each surface and then add them up. (correct answer)
Multiply the area of one surface by 6
Divide the total volume by the height of the prism
Find the area of the largest surface and multiply by the number of sides

hints.description: A prism has six sides. Each of the sides has its own surface area.

questions.question: Let’s start with the top or bottom faces (areaOfTopOrBottomFace). Put on your dancing shoes and set up the function, blues.

hints.description: A good formula uses easy-to-remember variables.  That way, we can allocate more brain power to reasoning. [fun equation]

questions.question: Let’s get snazzy and plug in the jazzie. (plug in the known values) | areaOfTopAndBottomFaces = length ✖️ width

questions.question: Let’s figure it out and shout it out. | areaOfTopOrBottomFace = 16 ✖️ 10

[trick with multiplication]

questions.question: Great!  Now let’s find areaOfOneSideFace.  Time to shine, let’s find the expression, so fine.

hints.description: A good formula uses easy-to-remember variables.  That way, we can allocate more brain power to reasoning. [fun equation]

questions.question: Time to get tricky and plug in the mickey. (plug in the known values) | areaOfOneSideFace = height ✖️ width

hints.description: Pretend each variable is a cup with tape on it that says the name of the cup.  You’re just dropping in the numbers into the cup. [Fun equation showing how variables can be used like numbers]

questions.question: Let’s work it out and remove the doubt. | areaOfOneSideFace = 8 ✖️ 10

hints.description: [basic double digit multiplication]
[trick with multiplication]

questions.question: We’re almost there!  Now we put it all together (totalSurfaceArea).  Get your groove on and set up the equation, come on.

hints.description: A good formula uses easy-to-remember variables.  That way, we can allocate more brain power to reasoning. [fun equation]

questions.question: Time to get sharp and plug in the harp. (plug in the known values) | totalSurfaceArea = (2 ✖️ areaOfTopOrBottomFace) + (4 ✖️ areaOfOneSideFace)

problem: A train leaves the station and travels at a speed of 100 miles per hour. Three hours later, a second train leaves the same station and travels at a speed of 120 miles per hour. questions.question: Explain to a giant box of tissues why we don’t care about train1_distance or train2_distance
options: We don’t need them. We need only the relative speed (train2_speed - train1_speed).  (correct answer)
We don’t need them. We need only the absolute speed (train2_speed + train1_speed).
We don’t need them. We need only the average speed ((train2_speed + train1_speed) / 2).
We don’t need them. We need only the speed difference (train1_speed - train2_speed).

questions.question: Let’s take a dive and solve this math five | area = 0.5 ✖️ 18 ✖️ 12

hints.description: [basic double digit multiplication]
0.5 ✖️ 18 = 18 / 2.  Multiplying anything by 0.5 is the same as dividing it by 2.
When multiplying (or dividing) 3+ numbers, order doesn’t matter.  You can rearrange this to “0.5 ✖️ 12 ✖️ 18” if you want.
